Development Practices to Avoid More Fervently than the Measles Unpublished

18 Jan 2018 â€¢ best practices teams php

A few years back I took a job as a developer and shortly thereafter, through surprising and inexplicable circumstances, I found myself as the lead of the project. The codebase that I took over was a rat's nest and I knew it was. However, I didn't know how to fix it nor did I know all that was wrong with it. I just had a feeling that all was not well in Mayberry.

Over the coming months, I mostly figured out what needed improving and I went about implementing those changes fervently. The following are a few things that I learned during that experience and later.

No Extraneous Code in Class Files or Interfaces

This is one of the longest ropes that you can hang yourself with while using a scripting language. You want to use a class and then there's a side-effect when you use it. This makes it nearly impossible to change the usage of said class or even the class file itself.

In addition, you'll find that such systems are pure spaghetti code. They're littered with messy and archaic coding practices that make it very time consuming to fix and improve. It is a monolithic beast that is difficult to slay and proves the point that fast is slow.
